title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: OneMeanDream provides enhanced one-sample t-test functionality advanced statistical approximations comprehensive diagnostics: üìä Wallace Critical Value Approximation accurate hypothesis testing üî¨ Hastings P-Value Approximation computational efficiency ‚úÖ Comprehensive Assumption Checking (Shapiro-Wilk normality test, outlier detection) üìà Diagnostic Plots (Q-Q plot, histogram normal curve overlay, boxplot)

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: can install development version OneMeanDream GitHub :

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: ‚Äôs basic example showing perform one-sample t-test:
code: library(OneMeanDream)  # Create sample data: test if earnings are significantly below $75k set.seed(181) earnings_data <- data.frame(   Earnings = round(rnorm(50, mean = 65, sd = 20), 0) )  # Perform one-sample t-test result <- oneMeanTTest(   x = "Earnings",    mu = 75,    ha = "less",    alpha = 0.05,    data = earnings_data,   plot = TRUE ) print(result) #>  #>     One-Sample t-test #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Variable:    Earnings  #> n:           50  #> Mean:        65.82  #> SD:          21.5792  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Null Hyp:    mu = 75  #> Alt Hyp:     mu < 75  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> ASSUMPTION CHECKS: #> 1. Normality (Shapiro-Wilk): SATISFIED (p = 0.905 ) #> 2. Outliers (1.5 IQR Rule):  SATISFIED (0 outliers detected) #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> t-stat:      -3.0081  #> df:          49  #> Crit Val:    -1.6765  #> P-value:     0.001543  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> 95% CI:      [ -Inf ,  70.9364 ] #> Decision:    REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho)  #>  #> Interpretation: #> At alpha = 0.05, we REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho). The sample mean (65.82) is significantly less than 75. #> We are 95% confident that the true population mean is less than 70.9364.

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text:
Uses Wallace approximation formula converting z-values t-distribution critical values: tŒ±=ŒΩ(ec‚ãÖzŒ±2/ŒΩ‚àí1)t_\alpha = \sqrt{
u \left(e^{c \cdot z_\alpha^2 / 
u} - 1ight)} c=(8ŒΩ+38ŒΩ+1)2c = \left( rac{8
u+3}{8
u+1}ight)^2 ŒΩ=n‚àí1
u = n-1 (degrees freedom).

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: Implements efficient 4-term Hastings approximation computing p-values without relying built-distribution functions, ensuring computational efficiency numerical stability.

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: function automatically performs: Normality Testing: Shapiro-Wilk test clear pass/fail indication Outlier Detection: Uses 1.5 √ó IQR rule identify potential outliers Q-Q plot normality assessment Histogram overlaid normal curve Boxplot highlighting outliers

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: x: Column name (character string) containing numeric data mu: Hypothesized population mean null hypothesis ha: Alternative hypothesis - "less", "greater", "equal" alpha: Significance level (required parameter) data: Data frame containing variable plot: Whether display diagnostic plots (default: TRUE)

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
text: function returns comprehensive list containing: Sample statistics (mean, SD, sample size) Test statistics (t-statistic, degrees freedom, critical value) P-value confidence interval Decision interpretation Assumption check results (normality test, outlier detection)

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
code: # Test if temperature differs from 98.6¬∞F temp_data <- data.frame(   Temperature = c(98.2, 98.6, 97.8, 99.1, 98.4, 98.7,                    97.9, 98.5, 98.3, 98.8, 98.1, 98.6) )  oneMeanTTest("Temperature", mu = 98.6, ha = "not equal",               alpha = 0.05, data = temp_data)

title: OneMeanDream - Enhanced One-Sample t-Test
code: # Test if scores are above 70 set.seed(456) scores <- data.frame(   Score = round(runif(40, min = 50, max = 95), 1) )  oneMeanTTest("Score", mu = 70, ha = "greater",               alpha = 0.05, data = scores)

what: OneMeanDream: Enhanced One-Sample t-Test with Diagnostics ‚Äî OneMeanDream-package
title: OneMeanDream: Enhanced One-Sample t-Test with Diagnostics ‚Äî OneMeanDream-package
text: Performs one-sample t-tests using Wallace critical value approximation Hastings p-value approximation. Includes comprehensive assumption checks (normality via Shapiro-Wilk, outlier detection) diagnostic plots.

title: OneMeanDream: Enhanced One-Sample t-Test with Diagnostics ‚Äî OneMeanDream-package
text: oneMeanTTest - Perform one-sample t-test diagnostics print.oneMeanTTest - Pretty print results

title: OneMeanDream: Enhanced One-Sample t-Test with Diagnostics ‚Äî OneMeanDream-package
text: Wallace approximation critical values 4-term Hastings approximation p-values Shapiro-Wilk normality test 1.5 * IQR outlier detection Diagnostic plots (Q-Q plot, histogram, boxplot) Detailed interpretation results

title: OneMeanDream: Enhanced One-Sample t-Test with Diagnostics ‚Äî OneMeanDream-package
text: Load package run basic test: library(OneMeanDream) # Sample data set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(x = rnorm(30, mean = 10, sd = 2)) # Run test result <- oneMeanTTest("x", mu = 10, ha = "equal", alpha = 0.05, data = data) # View results print(result)

what: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
text: Performs comprehensive one-sample t-test using Wallace approximation critical values 4-term Hastings approximation p-values. Includes normality testing, outlier detection, diagnostic plots (histogram, Q-Q plot, boxplot).

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
code: oneMeanTTest(x, mu, ha, alpha, data, plot = TRUE)

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
text: x Character string. Name numeric column data test. mu Numeric. Hypothesized population mean null hypothesis (H0: mu = mu0). ha Character string. Alternative hypothesis. One "less" (H1: mu < mu0), "greater" (H1: mu > mu0), "equal" (H1: mu != mu0). alpha Numeric. Significance level (0 < alpha < 1). Must explicitly provided. data Data frame containing column specified x. plot Logical. TRUE (default), display diagnostic plots: Q-Q plot, histogram normal curve, boxplot.

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
text: List class "oneMeanTTest" containing fields: variable: Tested variable name n: Sample size (removing NAs) sample_mean: Sample mean sample_sd: Sample standard deviation t_statistic: t-test statistic p_value: Hastings p-value confidence_interval: Confidence bounds decision: "REJECT" "FAIL REJECT" is_normal: Normality assumption met? outliers: Detected outliers

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
text:
Critical values use Wallace approximation: $$t_\alpha = \sqrt{
u (\exp(c \cdot z_\alpha^2 / 
u) - 1)}$$ \(c = ((8
u+3)/(8
u+1))^2\) \(
u = n-1\). P-values use 4-term Hastings approximation computational efficiency.

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
text: Normality (Shapiro-Wilk test, p > alpha) outliers (1.5 * IQR rule)

title: One-Sample t-Test with Wallace Critical Values and Hastings P-Values ‚Äî oneMeanTTest
code: # Example 1: Earnings data (suspected to be below $75k) set.seed(181) earnings_data <- data.frame(   Earnings = round(rnorm(50, mean = 65, sd = 20), 0) ) result <- oneMeanTTest("Earnings", mu = 75, ha = "less",                         alpha = 0.05, data = earnings_data)  print(result) #>  #>     One-Sample t-test #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Variable:    Earnings  #> n:           50  #> Mean:        65.82  #> SD:          21.5792  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Null Hyp:    mu = 75  #> Alt Hyp:     mu < 75  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> ASSUMPTION CHECKS: #> 1. Normality (Shapiro-Wilk): SATISFIED (p = 0.905 ) #> 2. Outliers (1.5 IQR Rule):  SATISFIED (0 outliers detected) #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> t-stat:      -3.0081  #> df:          49  #> Crit Val:    -1.6765  #> P-value:     0.001543  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> 95% CI:      [ -Inf ,  70.9364 ] #> Decision:    REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho)  #>  #> Interpretation: #> At alpha = 0.05, we REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho). The sample mean (65.82) is significantly less than 75. #> We are 95% confident that the true population mean is less than 70.9364.  #>   # Example 2: Test scores (check if above 70) set.seed(456) scores <- data.frame(   Score = round(runif(40, min = 50, max = 95), 1) ) oneMeanTTest("Score", mu = 70, ha = "greater",               alpha = 0.05, data = scores, plot = FALSE) #>  #>     One-Sample t-test #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Variable:    Score  #> n:           40  #> Mean:        75.9425  #> SD:          13.29  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Null Hyp:    mu = 70  #> Alt Hyp:     mu > 70  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> ASSUMPTION CHECKS: #> 1. Normality (Shapiro-Wilk): NOT SATISFIED (p = 0.00915 ) - Consider Wilcoxon Test #> 2. Outliers (1.5 IQR Rule):  SATISFIED (0 outliers detected) #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> t-stat:      2.828  #> df:          39  #> Crit Val:    1.6849  #> P-value:     0.00257  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> 95% CI:      [ 72.402 ,  Inf ] #> Decision:    REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho)  #>  #> Interpretation: #> At alpha = 0.05, we REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho). The sample mean (75.9425) is significantly greater than 70. #> We are 95% confident that the true population mean is greater than 72.402.  #>   # Example 3: Temperature readings (two-tailed test) temp_data <- data.frame(   Temperature = c(98.2, 98.6, 97.8, 99.1, 98.4, 98.7, 97.9,                    98.5, 98.3, 98.8, 98.1, 98.6) ) oneMeanTTest("Temperature", mu = 98.6, ha = "not equal",               alpha = 0.05, data = temp_data)  #>  #>     One-Sample t-test #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Variable:    Temperature  #> n:           12  #> Mean:        98.4167  #> SD:          0.3786  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> Null Hyp:    mu = 98.6  #> Alt Hyp:     mu != 98.6  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> ASSUMPTION CHECKS: #> 1. Normality (Shapiro-Wilk): SATISFIED (p = 0.996 ) #> 2. Outliers (1.5 IQR Rule):  SATISFIED (0 outliers detected) #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> t-stat:      -1.6775  #> df:          11  #> Crit Val:    2.2016  #> P-value:     0.09305  #> ------------------------------------------------------ #> 95% CI:      [ 98.176 ,  98.6573 ] #> Decision:    FAIL TO REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho)  #>  #> Interpretation: #> At alpha = 0.05, we FAIL TO REJECT the null hypothesis (Ho). The sample mean (98.4167) is not significantly not equal to 98.6. #> We are 95% confident that the true population mean is between 98.176 and 98.6573.  #>
